question: The model uses a **specified head boundary** condition at the right outlet. How can we modify the amount of outflow?
success: ✅ Correct! For our 1D model with one no-flow boundary, the outflow equals the recharge rate multiplied by the surface area (length x width). Only changes to the recharge rate will alter the total outflow.
error: ❌ Not correct. In our 1D steady-state model with one no-flow boundary, outflow is determined by the recharge rate only, not by hydraulic conductivity.

question: The model uses a **specified-head** boundary condition at the right outlet. The groundwater recharge is specified as 180 mm/a. What parameter change is suitable to increase the hydraulic head in the aquifer at the right boundary? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct! A specified-head boundary fixes the head, so no parameter change will affect it.
error: ❌ Not correct. The head at a Dirichlet boundary remains constant, regardless of other parameters.

question: The model uses a **head-dependent** boundary condition at the right outlet. The groundwater recharge is specified as 180 mm/a. What parameter change is suitable to **increase the outflow** at the boundary? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct! The total outflow is fixed by recharge. Changing $K$ or $C_{Riv}$ does not affect total discharge.
error: ❌ Not correct. Changing conductivity or conductance affects head distribution, not the total outflow given a constant recharge.

question: The model uses a **head-dependent** boundary condition (**River BC**) at the right outlet. The groundwater recharge is specified as 180 mm/a. What parameter change is suitable to **increase the hydraulic head** in the aquifer at the right boundary? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct! Lower $C_{Riv}$ increases the resistance between the aquifer model and the boundary, thus the aquifer heads must be higher to drive the same volume of water out of the boundary. Lowering  $K$ increases overall resistance of the aquifer requiring a steeper gradient and thus higher heads to discharge the same volume of water to the river
error: ❌ Not correct. Increasing hydraulic conductivity or conductance reduces the resistance to flow and therefore also heads.
